article.title: A Compact, Wide Field-of-View Gradient-index Lens Antenna for Millimeter-wave MIMO on Mobile Devices

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the color gradient in Figure 2 represent?
choices: The phase shift introduced by the lens.
The gain of the antenna at different points.
The relative permittivity of the lens material.
The electric field intensity within the lens.

multiple_choice_question.text: Which unit cell configuration theoretically allows for the lowest effective permittivity (ε_{eff})?
choices: Circular voids on a square lattice (Squ).
Circular voids on a triangular lattice (Tri).
Hexagonal void on a hexagonal lattice (Hex).
All configurations achieve the same minimum ε_{eff}.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the significance of the percentage values shown in Table 1?
choices: They represent the efficiency of each lens design.
They show the bandwidth of each lens antenna.
They indicate the percentage of unit cells with permittivity values below the fabrication limit for each configuration.
They represent the maximum achievable gain for each lens design.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the main advantage of the "Hex" unit-cell configuration at wider beam-steering angles?
choices: It results in a more compact lens design.
It minimizes the overall fabrication cost.
It allows for lower minimum permittivity, leading to better performance at wider scan angles.
It simplifies the feed network design.
